<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GOVERNMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/12/23/2020-review-coronavirus-explodes-distinctions-public-private-sectors?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Pubvate Sector
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="A man saying "shut down" " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=464 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/TlK63EEpq1DePsGR0Ag/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt='A man saying "shut down" ' style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/TlK63EEpq1DePsGR0Ag/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Normally, we think of government and business as operating like schoolkids and faculty. Even though one group supervises the other, they each do their own thing, occasionally quarreling but generally maintaining a state of peaceful coexistence. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Enter 2020. Facing the historic scope of the Covid-19 crisis, a <em>School of Rock </em>scenario emerged where divisions between the supervisors and the supervised were muddled as they collectively worked to <span style="text-decoration: line-through;">learn about music and this thing we call life</span> contain the coronavirus. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The first instance came in mid-March, when state governments <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/03/21/coronavirus-lockdown-orders-shelter-place-stay-home-state-list/2891193001/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ordered</a> certain businesses to close so we could “flatten the curve.” Suddenly, life got more local. We all became very familiar with our governors <a href="https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/04/whats-the-deal-with-andrew-cuomos-nipples.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">and their body piercings</a>. And without federal guidelines, those governors had flexibility in determining which businesses deserved the “essential” badge and would therefore be allowed to stay open. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>States </span><span><a href="https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/2020/03/24/coronavirus-state-measures-contain-disease-vary-widely/2897975001/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">very much differed</a></span><span> on that determination. And all of a sudden, whether or not you could open a hair salon depended mainly on whether that salon was in Atlanta or Albany. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Early on, business owners clashed with their elected leaders over social distancing restrictions. Those clashes continued over the summer, from <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/27/new-jersey-gym-owners-arrested-defying-state-health-mandate?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">New Jersey gyms</a> to <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/12/07/new-california-covid19-restrictions-face-pushback-small-businesses?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">California restaurants</a>. Just this month, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo’s decision to halt indoor dining in NYC <a href="https://ny.eater.com/2020/12/8/22158715/new-york-hospitality-groups-decry-governor-cuomo-indoor-dining-shutdown?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">caused an uproar</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Of course, business has always had to work with the government; 2020 didn’t invent the concept of regulation. But it has shown us the most extreme forms of government intervention in the private sector. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Another example? </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The Defense Production Act (DPA) </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This little-known law allows presidents to give businesses homework in service of imperiled national defense. Trump invoked it in mid-March to direct companies, including iconic automaker GM, to shift their operations and produce sorely needed ventilators. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A debate over the DPA and how to use it ensued, reflecting Americans’ ambivalence about the government going from “give that fryer another wipe if you want a license” to “we order you to make medical equipment instead of cars.” </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Trump had </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/31/us/politics/coronavirus-defense-production-act.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">initially resisted</a></span><span> using the DPA, comparing it to nationalization in failed states like Venezuela. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>But his critics quickly pointed out that the DPA is used thousands of times per year for military purposes, drawing attention to the significant amount of public-private sector overlap in the U.S. defense system. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In other words, while 2020 was a year of crisis, it exposed—and perhaps helped us to contemplate—just how intertwined government and business are in non-crisis times. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Then there’s the stimulus </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In March, the U.S. economy was chugging along with historically low unemployment, then it turned left at a sign marked “coronavirus” and chugged off a cliff. Congress <a href="https://apnews.com/article/2099a53bb8adf2def7ee7329ea322f9d?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">quickly passed</a> a rescue package of unprecedented scale: $2.2 trillion. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In 2019, you would have been shocked to learn that a few months into 2020 you would pine for that overcrowded, overpriced bar where it takes an hour to get a drink. You’d be even more shocked to learn that $2 trillion in government spending would be criticized as insufficient. But it was. The social distancing mandates necessary to getting the virus under control put businesses and the labor market in existentially dire straits. Remember this awful graph?   <img src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNjQvdW5lbXBsb3ltZW50X2NoYXJ0LnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiJ9" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em><a href="https://www.epi.org/press/unemployment-insurance-claims-jumped-nearly-1500-in-two-weeks-i-have-been-a-labor-economist-for-a-very-long-time-and-have-never-seen-anything-like-this/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Economic Policy Institute</a></em> </small></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s initial jobless claims for the week before March 26, the Labor Department’s biggest spike on record. Many economists agree the magnitude of the stimulus was beyond warranted, and for many critics, it wasn’t anywhere near enough. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>One University of California Berkeley economist </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/09/sunday-review/stimulus-congress-layoffs.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">argued</a></span><span> that to support testing early on, the government should have inserted itself even </span><span><em>more</em></span><span> into the private sector by guaranteeing test makers a return on their investments.  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">NYT economics reporter Noam Scheiber wrote, “Employers are generally willing to make investments when they believe that these investments will benefit their business. But they are reluctant to take on costs when it is primarily the public that benefits, in which case it falls to the government to step in.” In 2020, the government stepped in to a degree not seen before in our lifetimes. Now, even after a second $900 billion stimulus package was passed, lawmakers are in a heated debate over whether to send additional $2,000 checks to Americans. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The public x private collab’s greatest challenge is ahead </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Much of the lightning-quick rollout of vaccines can be attributed to <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/24/quick-teardown-operation-warp-speed?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Operation Warp Speed</a>, a government program that worked to grease the skids for pharma companies. And over the next few months, those companies will partner with the government to solve the logistical equivalent of a 100-sided Rubik’s cube: distributing vaccines to enough of the population to clamp down on the coronavirus once and for all. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The early results are not encouraging. With states slow to get shots in Americans' arms, the U.S. is unlikely to hit the Trump administration's goal of 20 million vaccinations by the end of 2020, reports Bloomberg. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>President-elect Joe Biden will be inaugurated on January 20, and he’s likely to take a more hands-on approach with the private sector than President Trump. He’s <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/22/stimulus-checks-biden-to-push-for-more-payments-in-next-covid-plan.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">promised</a> to wield the DPA to support healthcare efforts and <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-01/biden-calls-on-congress-to-pass-robust-package-for-stimulus?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">called for</a> even more stimulus.  </p>

</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">I’ve spent most of this year in stupefied awe of healthcare workers. I especially want to mention a moment I had with some nurses in Brooklyn. I went to get a Covid test about a month ago, waited in line for an hour, and braced myself for a painful nose swabbing from an exhausted, overworked, irritated person. Instead, the woman who swabbed my nose was gentle, kind, and even gave me directions to a place with gluten free bagels (I have Celiac disease). It’s not just the caring for people—it’s the maintaining a supportive bedside manner throughout that most impressed me. </p>

Q&A
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/12/23/meet-brew-writer-eliza-carter?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">

</font></a>
</h1>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Get to know the Brew writers better with a quick round of icebreakers.</em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Hometown: </strong>Millwood, VA...it’s technically too small to be an incorporated town. The closest real town is Berryville. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What you would be doing if not writing for the Brew:</strong> Trying to figure out a marketable use for earnings call-related wordplay. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">One thing you are snobby about: </strong>Leather. Whether it’s shoes or belts, if it’s not properly oiled, I’m not interested. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">First R-rated movie: </strong><em>Shakespeare in Love...</em>yes, I’m still recovering. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What is something fun you did that you’d never do again? </strong>Snowboarding. I enjoyed it, but for whatever reason, I like to slide down snowy hills on<em> two</em> fiberglass planks, not one. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">If you could safely eat any inedible object, what would it be?</strong> Most things that I love aggressively—my friends, my dogs, Andrew Rannells. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Recommend literally anything: </strong>This tip is now outdated, but I’m going to share it because it shocks people and it really, actually works. If you have a CD or DVD that’s smudgy (like I said, outdated, but let me finish) put it in...the toilet. Then flush. I’m not kidding. It works. </p>

SPONSORED BY BRIGHTCOVE

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nGOVERNMENT\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/12/23/2020-review-coronavirus-explodes-distinctions-public-private-sectors?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nThe Pubvate Sector\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A man saying \"shut down\" \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=464 src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/TlK63EEpq1DePsGR0Ag/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt='A man saying \"shut down\" ' style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/TlK63EEpq1DePsGR0Ag/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNormally, we think of government and business as operating like schoolkids and faculty. Even though one group supervises the other, they each do their own thing, occasionally quarreling but generally maintaining a state of peaceful coexistence. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eEnter 2020. Facing the historic scope of the Covid-19 crisis, a \u003cem\u003eSchool of Rock \u003c/em\u003escenario emerged where divisions between the supervisors and the supervised were muddled as they collectively worked to \u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: line-through;\"\u003elearn about music and this thing we call life\u003c/span\u003e contain the coronavirus. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe first instance came in mid-March, when state governments \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/03/21/coronavirus-lockdown-orders-shelter-place-stay-home-state-list/2891193001/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eordered\u003c/a\u003e certain businesses to close so we could “flatten the curve.” Suddenly, life got more local. We all became very familiar with our governors \u003ca href=\"https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/04/whats-the-deal-with-andrew-cuomos-nipples.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eand their body piercings\u003c/a\u003e. And without federal guidelines, those governors had flexibility in determining which businesses deserved the “essential” badge and would therefore be allowed to stay open. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eStates \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/2020/03/24/coronavirus-state-measures-contain-disease-vary-widely/2897975001/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003every much differed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e on that determination. And all of a sudden, whether or not you could open a hair salon depended mainly on whether that salon was in Atlanta or Albany. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eEarly on, business owners clashed with their elected leaders over social distancing restrictions. Those clashes continued over the summer, from \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/27/new-jersey-gym-owners-arrested-defying-state-health-mandate?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eNew Jersey gyms\u003c/a\u003e to \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/12/07/new-california-covid19-restrictions-face-pushback-small-businesses?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eCalifornia restaurants\u003c/a\u003e. Just this month, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo’s decision to halt indoor dining in NYC \u003ca href=\"https://ny.eater.com/2020/12/8/22158715/new-york-hospitality-groups-decry-governor-cuomo-indoor-dining-shutdown?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecaused an uproar\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOf course, business has always had to work with the government; 2020 didn’t invent the concept of regulation. But it has shown us the most extreme forms of government intervention in the private sector. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnother example? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe Defense Production Act (DPA) \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis little-known law allows presidents to give businesses homework in service of imperiled national defense. Trump invoked it in mid-March to direct companies, including iconic automaker GM, to shift their operations and produce sorely needed ventilators. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA debate over the DPA and how to use it ensued, reflecting Americans’ ambivalence about the government going from “give that fryer another wipe if you want a license” to “we order you to make medical equipment instead of cars.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eTrump had \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/31/us/politics/coronavirus-defense-production-act.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einitially resisted\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e using the DPA, comparing it to nationalization in failed states like Venezuela. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBut his critics quickly pointed out that the DPA is used thousands of times per year for military purposes, drawing attention to the significant amount of public-private sector overlap in the U.S. defense system. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn other words, while 2020 was a year of crisis, it exposed—and perhaps helped us to contemplate—just how intertwined government and business are in non-crisis times. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThen there’s the stimulus \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn March, the U.S. economy was chugging along with historically low unemployment, then it turned left at a sign marked “coronavirus” and chugged off a cliff. Congress \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/2099a53bb8adf2def7ee7329ea322f9d?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003equickly passed\u003c/a\u003e a rescue package of unprecedented scale: $2.2 trillion. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn 2019, you would have been shocked to learn that a few months into 2020 you would pine for that overcrowded, overpriced bar where it takes an hour to get a drink. You’d be even more shocked to learn that $2 trillion in government spending would be criticized as insufficient. But it was. The social distancing mandates necessary to getting the virus under control put businesses and the labor market in existentially dire straits. Remember this awful graph?   \u003cimg src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNjQvdW5lbXBsb3ltZW50X2NoYXJ0LnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiJ9\" class=\"img-responsive\" width=\"640\" style=\"width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;\" alt=\"\" data-reactroot=\"\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.epi.org/press/unemployment-insurance-claims-jumped-nearly-1500-in-two-weeks-i-have-been-a-labor-economist-for-a-very-long-time-and-have-never-seen-anything-like-this/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eEconomic Policy Institute\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e \u003c/small\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat’s initial jobless claims for the week before March 26, the Labor Department’s biggest spike on record. Many economists agree the magnitude of the stimulus was beyond warranted, and for many critics, it wasn’t anywhere near enough. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eOne University of California Berkeley economist \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/09/sunday-review/stimulus-congress-layoffs.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eargued\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e that to support testing early on, the government should have inserted itself even \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003emore\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e into the private sector by guaranteeing test makers a return on their investments.  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNYT economics reporter Noam Scheiber wrote, “Employers are generally willing to make investments when they believe that these investments will benefit their business. But they are reluctant to take on costs when it is primarily the public that benefits, in which case it falls to the government to step in.” In 2020, the government stepped in to a degree not seen before in our lifetimes. Now, even after a second $900 billion stimulus package was passed, lawmakers are in a heated debate over whether to send additional $2,000 checks to Americans. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe public x private collab’s greatest challenge is ahead \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMuch of the lightning-quick rollout of vaccines can be attributed to \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/24/quick-teardown-operation-warp-speed?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eOperation Warp Speed\u003c/a\u003e, a government program that worked to grease the skids for pharma companies. And over the next few months, those companies will partner with the government to solve the logistical equivalent of a 100-sided Rubik’s cube: distributing vaccines to enough of the population to clamp down on the coronavirus once and for all. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe early results are not encouraging. With states slow to get shots in Americans' arms, the U.S. is unlikely to hit the Trump administration's goal of 20 million vaccinations by the end of 2020, reports Bloomberg. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003ePresident-elect Joe Biden will be inaugurated on January 20, and he’s likely to take a more hands-on approach with the private sector than President Trump. He’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/22/stimulus-checks-biden-to-push-for-more-payments-in-next-covid-plan.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epromised\u003c/a\u003e to wield the DPA to support healthcare efforts and \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-01/biden-calls-on-congress-to-pass-robust-package-for-stimulus?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecalled for\u003c/a\u003e even more stimulus.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F12%2F23%2F2020-review-coronavirus-explodes-distinctions-public-private-sectors\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block; width: 25px\" width=\"25\" src=\"https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan\u003e  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ca collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eI’ve spent most of this year in stupefied awe of healthcare workers. I especially want to mention a moment I had with some nurses in Brooklyn. I went to get a Covid test about a month ago, waited in line for an hour, and braced myself for a painful nose swabbing from an exhausted, overworked, irritated person. Instead, the woman who swabbed my nose was gentle, kind, and even gave me directions to a place with gluten free bagels (I have Celiac disease). It’s not just the caring for people—it’s the maintaining a supportive bedside manner throughout that most impressed me. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eGet to know the Brew writers better with a quick round of icebreakers.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHometown: \u003c/strong\u003eMillwood, VA...it’s technically too small to be an incorporated town. The closest real town is Berryville. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat you would be doing if not writing for the Brew:\u003c/strong\u003e Trying to figure out a marketable use for earnings call-related wordplay. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOne thing you are snobby about: \u003c/strong\u003eLeather. Whether it’s shoes or belts, if it’s not properly oiled, I’m not interested. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFirst R-rated movie: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cem\u003eShakespeare in Love...\u003c/em\u003eyes, I’m still recovering. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat is something fun you did that you’d never do again? \u003c/strong\u003eSnowboarding. I enjoyed it, but for whatever reason, I like to slide down snowy hills on\u003cem\u003e two\u003c/em\u003e fiberglass planks, not one. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIf you could safely eat any inedible object, what would it be?\u003c/strong\u003e Most things that I love aggressively—my friends, my dogs, Andrew Rannells. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eRecommend literally anything: \u003c/strong\u003eThis tip is now outdated, but I’m going to share it because it shocks people and it really, actually works. If you have a CD or DVD that’s smudgy (like I said, outdated, but let me finish) put it in...the toilet. Then flush. I’m not kidding.
